subject: Economics
title: Voting Theory: Why No System Is Perfect
description: A micro-lesson that makes Voting Theory: Why No System Is Perfect usable.

hook.text: Arrow's Impossibility Theorem: no voting system with 3+ candidates can satisfy all fairness criteria simultaneously.

buildup.text: Kenneth Arrow proved in 1951 that ranked voting systems can't be non-dictatorial, Pareto efficient.

discovery.text: This isn't academic. Ralph Nader's 2000 campaign arguably cost Al Gore the presidency.

twist.text: Ranked-choice voting, approval voting, and quadratic voting each solve some problems but create others.

climax.text: Arrow's theorem doesn't mean democracy is pointless.

punchline.text: The perfect voting system doesn't exist. Arrow proved it mathematically.

quiz.question: What does Arrow's Impossibility Theorem prove?
options: No ranked voting system with 3+ candidates can simultaneously satisfy all reasonable fairness criteria
All voting systems are equally good
